newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends down on high output.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends down on high output.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures ended down in active trading on Wednesday, on expectations of higher copper output and imports and overnight losses on the London Metal Exchange, traders said.
The most active December 1996 contract ended at 20,500 yuan ($2,468) per tonne, down 140 yuan. It opened at 20,520 yuan, hitting an intra-day high of 20,550 and a low of 20,450.
September fell 80 to 21,000 yuan, October 110 to 20,740, November 50 to 20,550, the January 1997 contract 150 to 20,490 and February 160 to 20,500.
Combined volume rose sharply to 24,345 tonnes from 6,095.

"Some institutions supported copper at around the 20,500 level today but will be helpless if copper on the LME stays at the $1,900 level," he added. Analysts said the technical rebound of the past few weeks was not strong enough to push contracts above 21,000 yuan.
"Fundamentals and technical charts show that copper has more room to fall than to rise," a analyst said.
Aluminium ended little changed. September closed unchanged at 14,650 yuan, October rose 100 to 14,400 and November unchanged at 14,350.
Combined volume rose to 220 tonnes from 75.
